div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,576] ALEXANDRIA, Monday, August 20, 1906. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 1 May to 31 October.
Subject to the usual 25% reduction for returning.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

Passengers returning by the Line will be granted a rebate of 33% off the full fare i.e. Liverpool to Port Said £ 11.6.8. and Marseilles to Port Said £ 8.0.0.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

Departures from Alexandria same day in afternoon at 4 p.m.

TOURIST AND GENERAL PASSENGER AGENTS. BANKERS.
BAGGAGE AND FORWARDING AGENTS.
Officially appointed & Sole Agents in Cairo to the P.&O. S.N. Co.

RESIDENTS IN EGYPT proceeding to Europe for the summer are requested to apply to our offices for information respecting their Passages, where steamer plans may be consulted and Berths secured by all Lines of Steamers to all parts of the Globe; arrangements can also be made for the collection and forwarding of their baggage and clearance at port of arrival.

CIRCULAR NOTES issued payable at the current rate of exchange in all the principal cities of Europe. Cook’s Interpreters in uniform are present at the principal Railway stations and Landing-places in Europe to assist passengers holding their travelling tickets.

Large and splendidly appointed steamers belonging to the Co. leave Cairo thrice weekly, between November and March, for Luxor, Assouan and Wady-Halfa in connection with trains de luxe to Khartoum. Moderate fares.
FREIGHT SERVICE, Steamers leave Cairo every Saturday and Tuesday for Assouan and Halfa.
Special Steamers and Dahabeahs for private parties.

div.head: Austrian Lloyd’s Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Trieste (Venice).

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi, Tuesday 5 a.m. in time for express to Milan, Lucerne, Paris, Vienna, Berlin, and London, leaving Brindisi 7 a.m. Arrival Trieste Wednesday about 11 a.m. in connection with Train de Luxe Trieste-Vienna-Ostende. Passengers reach London every Friday 4.50 p.m.
Fortnightly Service: Alexandria-Brindisi & Trieste Line.
Steamer leaves Alexandria on or about 15 and 29 August, 12 and 26 September.

div.head: DES ENFANTS, LE DÉLICE!
div.p: C'est l'Emulsion Scott, si douce au palais que les bébés la prennent par gourmandise et si légère à l'estomac qu'ils la digèrent sans difficulté! Et quel bonheur aussi pour vous, chères mamans, d'avoir la réconfortante certitude de pouvoir, avec cette salutaire
EMULSION SCOTT,

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.
div.p: SUBSCRIPTIONS.—Alexandria, Cairo, and the Interior of Egypt (including delivery in Alexandria or postage to subscriber’s address) P.T. 231½ per annum, P.T. 116 for six months, P.T. 80 for three months. To other countries in the Postal Union P.T. 273 (£2.16s.) per annum. Six months P.T. 136½ (£1.8s.), three months P.T. 92 (£0.19s.) N.B.—Subscriptions commence from the 1st or 16th of any month.

ADVERTISEMENTS.—P.T. 4 per line. Minimum charge P.T. 20. Births, Marriages, or Deaths, not exceeding three lines, P.T. 20. Every additional line P.T. 10. Notices in news column P.T. 20 per line. Contracts entered into for standing advertisements.
ADVERTISEMENTS and SUBSCRIPTIONS are due in advance. P.O. Orders and Cheques to be made payable to the Editor and Manager, Rowland Snelling, Alexandria.
London Offices : 36, New Broad-street. B.C.
THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE can be obtained in London at our office, 36, New Broad Street, E.C.
Cairo Offices.-No. 1 Sharia Vervudachi, (opposite the Agricultural Bank.)

div.head: BIRTH
div.p: Gritchley.-At Alexandria, on the 19th inst., the wife of T.A.F Critchley, of a son.

div.head: LES BEBES DEPERISSENT TOUT COMME LES FLEURS!
div.p: Lorsque vous voyez vos enfants deperir, se faner comme les fleurs dans la terre dessechee, il est grand temps, croyez-le, d'avoir recours a PEMULSION SCOTT qui s’est si souvent montree la seve revivifiante de ces tendres fleurs que sont les bebes.

div.head: The Egyptian Gazette
div.p: The English Dally Newspaper, Established 1330 Editor and Manager - - R. Snelling Price: ONE PIASTRE TARIFF.
MONDAY, AUGUST 20, 1906.
HANDS OFF EGYPT!

To-morrow (says the “Pall Mall Gazette” of Tuesday last) his Majesty the King is to meet the German Emperor, and it is no secret that important affairs of State will occupy the attention of the two Sovereigns. First and foremost, as we must suppose, there will be the consideration of what steps it may be possible to take to assist the Tsar and the Russian Imperial family in the event of contingencies which are, at least, within the bounds of possibility. Then, presumably, they will exchange views upon the whole situation in Russia ; and, lastly, upon the somewhat delicate subject of the relations between their own respective countries. In that last con¬nection it is instructive to note that the German Press has made, as yet, absolutely no response whatever to those overtures of friend¬ship which have been so lavishly poured out in England during the past few months. On the contrary, the welcome—if such we may call it — extended to the British Sovereign by a Press of which the representatives were hospitably, and even enthusiastically, entertained at Windsor a few weeks ago, comes as near to positive rudeness as the circumstances permit. Of that, however, we do not com¬plain in the least : contrariwise, we prefer it, not only because it may possibly have some effect in diminishing the volume of the cataract of soapy sentimentality which will probably overflow a certain portion of our own Press during the next few days, but also because sincerity is preferable to insincerity, and, in the present instance, may tend to awaken a good many people (who badly want awakening) to the truth about the relations, present and future, between England and Germany. What, then, is it that the German Government is looking for from this meeting of the monarchs? If we may believe the “National Zeitung,” which is hardly likely to speak without know- ledge on such an occasion, while the Russian situation supplies the chief reason for the meeting, there is another. England, we are told, desires to regulate the affairs of Egypt as soon as possible, and to make the proposed settle¬ment seem plausible in the eyes of Germany. Again, as we learn from the Berlin correspon¬dent of the “Times,” the “Deutsche Revue” discusses the Egyptian “question” from the German standpoint, and proposes that Egypt should be treated “as an object of common interest to England and Germany, and that its future should be decided between the two Powers on the basis of compensating values.” In short, in this find in other matters the two nations must effect settlements “upon a footing of confiding reciprocity.”

It is, no doubt, a little difficult to keep one’s temper in the face of the unabashed impudence of the German assumption that there is still an “Egyptian question” which requires “settlement” with Germany or, for that matter, any other Power. Nevertheless, let us draw upon the materia medica of our philosophy for a stiff dose of patience, and try to understand what our German friends are driving at. The “Deutsche Revue” is, it must be admitted, delightfully frank. It seeks to use Lord Cromer’s proposal of certain chan¬ges which would affect the status of foreigners in Egypt as a means of extorting British consent to give Germany a free hand on the shore of the Persian Gulf in the matter of the terminus of the Baghdad Railway. “For England to persist in her policy of transform¬ing the Persian Gulf into a mare clausum Britannicum would be to throw down the gauntlet, and her persistence would com¬pel us to meet British wishes with the same measure.” In other words, Germany threatens that she will treat Egypt as she has treated Morocco, and will try to obtain “compensation for the abandonment of her rights.” Now, that is a policy which no British Government can possibly tolerate. Germany’s legitimate in-terests in the Nile Valley, which are purely commercial, are infinitesimally small, and unless she had interests there as great as those of France, with all the tradition of historical relations such as those of France with Egypt behind her, we could not consent to treat Egypt as “an object of common interest be¬tween England and Germany.’’ There is no such “common interest,” and the German assertion that there is can only he regarded as an impudent attempt to levy blackmail. The rights of all foreigners, Germans with the rest, will be as scrupulously safeguarded in the future as in the past; but Egypt is, and must remain, to all intents and purposes, a British Protectorate. Whatever be the outcome of the Baghdad Railway question, it certainly not be settled by Germany’s offer to abandon “rights” in Egypt which she has never possessed. That is a consideration to be commended to the notice of those among our own people who are perpetually repeating that we have no grounds of difference with Germany. We have none; but ever since the success of the German veto upon the Anglo-French Agree¬ment in Morocco, Germany has evidently meditating the discovery of a ground of differ¬ence with us—and that ground is Egypt. In order to foment that difference, Germany has egged on the Turk to assert himself in the Pen¬insula of Sinai, as he is defying France (doubt¬less by-the same inspiration) in the hinterland f Tripoli. So long as Germany continues to play her game of blackmail, so long will it be impossible for us to arrive at that good understanding with her which all parties in England desire. Germany must be made to realise that Egypt is a piece in the game of chess which has been definitely swept off the board by Great Britain. Wherefore, to all such proposals as are suggested by the German Press there is only ore possible answer— Hands off Egypt 1”

div.head: franco-Egyptian Convention.
div.p: The decree ratifying the Commercial Con-vention between France and Egypt is pu¬blished in the French “Official Journal.”

div.head: Brute In Human Shape.
div.p: Advices from Maghaga report the arrest of a certain Mohamed Abou Zeid, who was interrupted in the act of burning the body of his wife, whom he had strangled.

div.head: Beyrout Family of Nine Drowned.
div.p: Among the survivors of the Sirio disaster was M. Faltat-Horat, of Beyrout, who was making the voyage with his family, consisting of ten persons, of whom he is the sole survivor.

div.head: New Quay Estate.
div.p: The next sale of the Municipal estate on the new quay will take place in October. After that date there will be auctions of this land at regular intervals until the total amount of the land fixed by the Commission for sale has been disposed of.

div.head: A Forger.
div.p: Mahmoud Hamdi el.Mutargim, who recently managed to escape from custody on the charge of forging telegraphic money orders, has been apprehended by the Cairo police. The official enquiry showed that Mahmoad Hamdi had committed forgeries to the extent of L.E. 400 during the last three months.

div.head: San Stefano Casino.
div.p: The fete de unit at San Stefano on Saturday fully realized the expectations of the large throng who filled the grounds of this popular Casino. The Bracale orchestra and the Phil¬harmonic Band vied with each other in their musical efforts, and the evening wound up with a magnificent firework display.

div.head: A Local Composer.
div.p: Among the items of music to be played by the band of the 2nd Batt. Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers in the Esbekieh Gardens tomorrow evening. appears a march, “The Rising Nile,” composed by Lieut-Colonel J. Donegan, R.A.M.C., who is at present in medical charge of the troops at Kasr e'-Nil. The arrangement for military band has been made by Bimbashi Franklin, Musical Director, Egyptian Army.

div.head: Cairo Motor Accident
div.p: The enquiry into the motor car accident which resulted in the death of a lady and injuries to Yessin Bey Mustapha, has shown that the motor car was being driven at too high a speed, and that the cart with which it collided carried no light Such, at least, was the evidence elicited from Gamila Saidla, a woman servant who was accompanying them. According to her, Dame Aisha Fadel was a close relative of the Moudir, and was a frequent caller at his house, and it was while returning to her own home that the accident took place.

div.head: Armenian Lawlessness.
div.p: There was an echo of the racial feuds in the Ottoman Empire in Alexandria yesterday afternoon, when four Armenians attacked a Greek in Mohamed-Aly square because he was selling the Alexandria Greek newspaper, “Byzantium.” Our contemporary has offended Armenian susceptibilities by venturing to publish a portrait of the Orthodox Bishop of Anchialos in Eastern Roumelia. This prelate is disliked by the Armenians and so these men thrashed the Greek newsvendor and tore his papers to tatters. They were arrested and released on bail.

div.head: Taximeters for Alexandria.
div.p: A local newspaper stated that it had been decided to fit up the Alexandria cabs with taximeters. This statement is not correct, and was evidently based on the fact that a re¬presentative of a French firm of manufacturers of taximeters had submitted a proposal to the Municipality. As we un¬derstand that each taximeter costs about frs. 200, it is not likely that the proprietors of cabs will see their way to adopt it, especially as they are very pleased with the present cab tariff, which is considered most equitable for all the parties concerned.

div.head: NEW ABBAS THEATRE.
SIGNORINA LE0NI'S BENEFIT.
div.p: The final performance of The Geisha at the New Abbas Theatre on Friday night was very properly devoted to the benefit of Signs. Baldi, who, invariably welcome to Cairo audiences, has so largely contributed to the success of that piece, which has been the best received of all the company’s wide reper¬toire. Large as the theatre is, it was almost full, and great was the applause accorded to the much feted Mimosa San when she appeared on the stage.

The Italian translation is rather a grotesque parody of the popular English play, and though the staging was certainly excellent, many of the costumes were quite incomprehensible. To see the naval officers appear in military uniform made one smile, but even greater merriment was provoked by the sight of a sailor in kilts! As regards the musical representation of the piece, there was not much fault to be found, but Mimosa San treated that pretty '‘Goldfish" song with great cruelty by singing it in such painfully slow time, and we cannot understand why the finest of all the songs, 'Star of my Soul,” should have been omitted. Despite these faults, however, the play went with an ex¬cellent swing, and Bignorine Baldi and Leoni, and Signori Urbano and Pirracini especially distinguished themselves in the principal characters of Mimosa San, Molly Seamore, Wun Hi, and Marquis Imaro, respectively.

div.head: TERRIBLE FATALITY.
Princes AUTOMOBILE COLLIDES WITH TRAIN.
div.p: (Gazette’s Special Service.) LONDON, August 20. Prince Mohamed Ibrahim, whilst motoring between Bcrnay and Cormeilles, smashed violently into a train at the level crossing between Paris and Cherbourg at 7.30 o'clock on Saturday night Both the Prince and his chauffeur are dead. According to the evidence taken, the Prince's automobile was travelling at an excessive rate of speed. PARIS, August 18. An automobile conveying the Egyptian Prince Ibrahim Mohamed collided with a train near Bernay. The Prince has been seriously injured. (Reuter 1 PARIS, August 18. The automobile of Prince Mohamed Ibrahim (aged 38), cousin of H.H. the Khedive, ran into the engine of a train while crossing the Cherbourg road. It was entirely destroyed. The Prince’s condition is desperate. The chauffuer has already succumbed. (Havas) PARIS, August 19. Prince Ibrahim Mohamed is dead. (Reuter) PARIS, August 19. The newspapers state that Prince Mohamed Ibrahim died in the evening. (Havas) BERNAY, August 19. Prince Mohamed Ibrahim succumbed after having undergone a trepanning operation. (H.) [Bernay, where the catastrophe occurred, is on the main line to Cherbourg, between Evreux and Lisienx. It is a town of 7,966 inhabitants, and is the capital of the arrondissement of the Eure. The Chemin de Fer de l’Ouest passes through the town, and while crossing this railway line the Prince met with the accident.] A private telegram from Cherbourg to the Daira received as we go to Press states that the Prince breathed his last at 9.30 o’clock yesterday evening. He was alone in his automobile with his chauffeur. The Mayor of Cherbourg sent a telegram dated 4 p.m. yesterday to the Prince’s Daira at Alexandria to the effect that his High¬ness's condition was “tres grave.’’ Prince Mohamed Bey Ibrahim was the son of Prince Ibrahim Ahmed, tin cousin of the Khedive, and brother to H H. Prince Seif el Din, who is living in England. He was only 28 years of age, not 38, as stated in the Havas telegram. The Prince was married twice. Seven years ago he married Princess Fazilah, the daughter of Prince Osman Fazil. He had a son by the first wife who is now six years of age. After the death of Princess Fazilah, five years ago, his Highness married Prioress Salihab, daughter of Prince Ibrahim Hilmy, uncle of the Khedive, by whom be had two children, one a daughter who is now four years old, and the other a son, now two and a half years of age. The Prince was the biggest landlord in the neighbourhood of Alexandria. The Alex¬andria Sporting Club’s grounds is on his pro¬perty, and he possessed a great deal of land in the city, including the large buildings in Mohamed Aly-. square where the offices of the Banco di Roma are situated. It is stated that the Prince was offered lately L.E. 2,200,000 for his estates in Alexandria and Cairo, but refused, as he wanted £3.000,000. Prince Mohamed and his wife and children left Alexandria last month for France and took up their residence in the Prince's Parisian mansion in rae Callipert. His Highness was an ardent motorist and had already met with a terrible accident in Cairo the season before last, on the Pyramids road, when two European ladies who were with him, Mrs. Schrager and Mrs. Vuronoff, were also seriously injured.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: The “Standard” of the 14th inst. contains the following announcement ' The Khedive of Egypt, who left Cowes for Ostend, is now at Spa.” No other paper states that the Khedive has visited England, so either the news is erroneous or the strictest incognito was preserved.

div.head: BAND PERFORMANCE.
div.p: By kind permission of Major C. J. L, Davidson, D.S.O., commanding, and officers, 2nd Batt. Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers, the band will play the following programme of music in the Esbekieh Gardens on Tuesday from 9 to 11 p.m. March-Heldenruf-Leitmann. Overture--Merry Wives of Windsor—Nikola. Walzer- Ander Schonen Blauen Donau-Strauss. Fantasia-Maritana-Wallace. Serenade—Siziletta-Von Blon. Selection—Faust —Gounod. March—The Rising Nile - Lieut Col. J. Donegan (R.A.M.C. American Sketch —Way down in Tennessee— (Knowles. Regimental March. Khedivial Anthem. -God Save the King. R. WATSON RAMSEY, Bandmaster

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Moss liner Khephren sailed from Liverpool on Friday last, and is due here about the 31st inst. with passengers, mails and general cargo.

div.head: THE EXISTENCE OF FANATICISM.
div.p: In a letter which we have received from a correspondent at Port Sudan we are informed that ever since the commencement of the Akaba affair considerable unrest has been evident among the Sudanese of that district, and, our correspondent remarks, 'the existence of fanaticism thereabouts cannot be denied.”

No uneasiness is said to exist among the English inhabitants, who realise that any trouble which might be brewing would very soon be discovered and that immediate steps would be taken to convince the natives of the futility of any outbreak. The couple of hundred or so Greeks in Port Sudan show, however, a most unreasonable fear of an outbreak, and scares among them are frequent.
On our part, we are convinced that Colonel Drury, Governor of that province, will be able to maintain perfect order, and we would advise our Greek friends of Port Sudan to reassure themselves.

div.head: ENGLISHMAN’S GRAVE DESECRATED.
SEARCH FOR BOOTY.
div.p: We learn from Port Sudan that Mr. Cross, an ex-soldier and foreman of works at Port Sudan, died the week before last from heat apoplexy. On the day following the burial it was found that the railings round the unfortunate man's grave had been pulled down and that the grave had been reopened. The body was found in the grave, apparently undisturbed, and it is thought that some of the Sudanese from the adjacent village had opened the grave in the hopes of finding booty.
In spite of most searching inquiries no evidence has been found to convict any of the villagers of this horrible act of desecration.

div.head: AN AWKWARD DILEMMA
RESULT OF WASH OUTS IN SUDAN.
div.p: Considerable inconvenience has been caused by the recent wash-outs which have been experienced on the Port Sudan railway. Parts of the line have been broken up and the tele¬graphic communication has suffered greatly.

At the time of the first of these washouts, which we reported a short while ago, Bimbashi Lord was up in the hills some eighty miles from Port Sudan and suddenly found himself altogether cut off from the nearest villages and without provisions. The telegraph line to Port Sudan being broken, the only means by which Bimbashi Lord could obtain assistance was by telegraphing to Atbara, which he did by 'tapping” a wire, and from there the message was transmitted to Cairo. From Cairo the officer's urgent summons was telegraphed to Suez, and thence to Port Sudan. In this round¬about way the unfortunate position of Bimbashi Lord was made known to his fellow-officers at Port Sudan, from where provisions and help were sent with the utmost rapidity.

div.head: TURKISH TRANSPORT’S DISTRESS-
RESCUED BY B. I. STEAMER,
(FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT).
div.p: Suez, Sunday. The British India steamer Warora (Capt. A. E. Stebbing) arrived at Suez this morning from Bombay, having in tow the Turkish troopship Bars, which has on board 302 troops and 45 of a crew, from Hodeidah bound to Constan¬tinople.

The Warora sighted the Bars 17 miles south of Ras Garib, in the Gulf of Suez, at 8.30 am. on the 18th inst. She was in distress, her engines being disabled, and she was drifting towards the shore ; in about half an hour’s time she would have been on the rooks and broken up.

The commander and troops of the Turkish transport were in terrible straits, and as they possessed no flags to signal with they were seen desperately waving and crying out for assistance, their only distress signal being the ship’s ensign halfmasted. The Warora, at great risk, owing to the heavy sea and strong wind, and also her close proxi¬mity to the land, approached the Bars and by mean of rockets threw lines to her. Finally she managed to get hold of the trans-port and tow her to Suez safely, after first getting the tow hawser parted, and the maneuvers had to repeated with greater risk owing to the ship drifting rapidly closer and closer to the shore.

The plan of passing ropes from one vessel to another in a heavy sea, where there is great danger attending the lowering of boats, has apparently never been attempted before, and is entirely an idea of Captain Stebbing, to whom, as well as to the officers, great credit must be given for saving the lives of so many people, who would have very likely perish¬ed were it not for the prompt assistance rendered.

div.head: GAMBLING AT SAN STEFANO
VILLA MARGHERITA RAIDED.
div.p: Early yesterday morning the Alexandria City Police, including Hacheen Bey and two detectives, made a raid on the Villa Margherita, an hotel at San 8tefano, while gambling was proceeding.
On the arrival of the police a scene of great excitement ensued, but no arrests were made. £20 and the gambling material were confiscated by the police.

div.head: THE CAPITULATIONS.
THEIR ORIGIN.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE." Sir,—A common error, shared largely by the European colonies in the Ottoman dominions, is that the Capitulations were granted only to subjects of foreign Powers. This is not so. Originally, the scope of the Capitulations comprised all non Musaulmans, resident in Turkey. If we accept the verdict of history these Capitulations were first granted, not by the Turkish Sultans, but by the Greek Emperors, to the foreign colonies within their realm, such as the Genoese, the Pisans, and the Venetians. After the Fall of Constantinople, Mahomed II., desirous of reconciling the Greeks for the loss of their political liberties, by allowing them a certain measure of their previous communal privileges, ratified the Capitulations which the Greek Lords of Byzantium had conferred upon the Latin colonies, and by a wise and masterly stroke of policy, the effects of which have lasted to this day, extended and fair proportion of those benefits to his new nor.-Mussulman subjects, chief amongst which of course at that time were the Orthodox Greeks ; and these benefits were, inter alia, that they should be governed by their own municipal laws, have their own Patriarchal Court and Justinian Code, be free of military service—in tact enjoy just as much self-government as do the foreign Colonies now with the exception of those penal and civil matters which were ultra vires of the Patriarchal Court. Moreover, the ground- work of these original Byzantine Capitulations has served as the basis of all subsequent treaties between the Ottoman Porte and Christian Princes.

An interesting and conclusive relict of this state of things is the fact that the Consul of a European Power is even to-day described in official documents, such as the exequatur, as the “Bayle,” a title borrowed from that which the head of the Genoese or Venetian colony held under the Lower Empire, and which he continued to hold under the Turks.

It was this "authority and immemorial prestige” to which I referred in my letter to you of August 4 as bound to suffer by the abolition of the Capitulations, not so much from juridicial privilege as from political status, of which more anon.

Greek Orthodoxy, therefore, in common with the several other communities, Christian and Hebrew, subject to, and resident within the dominions of the Sublime Ottoman Ports, have in greater or less degrees privileges just as valid as those of the colonies of foreign Powers. In the case of the Greek community these privileges are accentuated by the fact that the Orthodox Greek Church is the Christian State religion in Turkey. The (Ecumenical Patriarch is officially just as much the head of the Greek nation as is the Sultan the Caliph of the Mohamedans, or the Pope Pontiff of the Holy Roman Empire. The Greek Church is styled the Great Church, and claims precedence in all State cere¬monies, the Patriarch being alone permitted to represent the other religions commu¬nities, and as conclusive proofs of his high rank, the Sultan rises upon the entry of his (Ecumenical Holiness ; a mark of respect which is not shown to the Grand Vizier. I might enumerate various other items of Patriarchal privileges, such as the military honours, but the fact of his spiritual equality with the Sultan will suffice.
I now come to the crux of the question. Strictly speaking, and according to prece¬dents which are indisputable, the abolition of the Capitulations in the form proposed by Lord Cromer is impossible.

Firstly, because that measure applies to a vilayet of the Ottoman Porte, and not to the whole system of the Empire; secondly, because to become effective it must require a special Irade of the Sultan; thirdly, because to conform to the spirit of impartiality with which it has been conceived, it must apply to all the non-Mussulman communities resident within this Ottoman vilayet.

The abolition of the Capitulatiols in the sense Lord Cromer has suggested by excluding the subject non Mussulman communities would render the status of those communities in Egypt null and void ; it would subject to the Egyptian authority, and not the Ottoman Porte, all those Christian and Jewish com¬munities whose supreme authority is at Constantinople.

Thus, were the abolition realised, the Greek Patriarch of Alexandria would discover himself severed from the (Ecumenical Patriarchate of Constantinople, and, to carry the point further, would require from the Khedive, and not the Sultan, that Irade for the journey which I mentioned in my letter.

To sum up, my contentions are that the status of these non Mussulman communities of Ottoman nationality in Egypt has been over-looked in Lord Cromer's scheme; that to be thorough, that abolition must include them as well; that the effect of that measure will make the status of the Patriarchate of Alex¬andria an anomaly, by rendering it independent of the (Ecumenical Patriarchate without pro¬vision for a readjustment of its relations with the local Egyptian authority; that a special Irade is necessary from H.I.M. the Sultan for the abolition of the Capitulations, which would then, to be effective, have to apply to the Empire at large.

Opposition to Lord Cromer, to which a correspondent objected, although it might exist, as I know it to do, could not very well be officially expressed by a subordinate of the (Ecumenical Patriarchate of Constantinople, who alone has the prerogative to voice the views of the Orthodox Greek Church and the Greek nation.

The only solution to the difficulty would be a form of Protectorate exercised in Egypt by one or other of the Powers subject to the spiritual authority of the Orthodox Patriarch, such as Russia or Greece, and similar to that which France wields in the Levant over the Oriental Latin communities, subject to Turkey. —Yours, etc., XENOS. Alexandria, 17th August 1906. [P.S.—I note the quibble ie personal status is this not also included in civil law? My lawyer says it is,

div.head: ALEXANDRIA SPORTING CLUB.
AUGUST SKYE MEETING.
div.p: Saturday’s Skye Meeting on the A. S. C. ground was uneventful and unexciting. There was a remarkably small attendance of the public, and few of the regular race-goers were to be seen in the enclosure, which bore a more or less deserted appearance The racing did not present any features of interest, the only close finish being afforded by the Bulkeley Plate. The betting, too, was not very animated, and on the whole the meeting met with but mediocre success. The afternoon was warm, but a cool breeze came from the sea. The band of the Royal Dublin Fusiliers helped to while away the time by a choice selection of music. The following is a description of the various events:—

SAN STEFANO PLATE of P.T. 2,500, viz: P.T. 2000 to winner and P.T. 500 to 2nd horse. For Arab ponies that have never won a race of the net value of P.T. 2,000 or more. Weight for age and inches. Distance 6 furlongs.

Ibrahim Bey Cherif's g.a.p. Kara Aslan, 10.3. Burnham. 1 Khalil Pasha Khayat's g.a b. Kawkab, 10.7. Thompson. 2 Isbak Bey Hussein’s g.a.p. Nadim, 10 7. Fen¬wick. 3 Saleh Bey Yaghen’s b.a.p. Bulkeley, 10.3. Claridge. 4 Ibrahim Bey Cherif's c.a.p. Ghazi, 9.13. Pericles. 0 Prince Omar Pasha Tonssoun's g.a.b Mleyhan, 9.13. B. Parsons. 0 Hassan Bey Kheir El Din’s b.a.p. Gawaber, 10.3. Koukidis. 0 Mr. A. J. Sursock’s b br.a.h. Phintias (late Roi de l'Air II), 10.7. Challoner. 0

Kara Aslan made all the running, and won by a couple of lengths from Kawkab, who, when reaching the polo house, made a des¬perate attempt to get on terms with the leader, but was too late to prove dangerous. 3 lengths divided 2nd and 3rd. Time 1.23.
Totalisator paid P.T. 35 on winner P.T. 27, 30, and 59 for places.
8CHUTZ PLATE of P.T. 1,250. viz: P.T. 1000 to winner and P.T. 250 to 2nd horse. For Arabs that have never won a race of the net value of P.T. 2,000 or more. Weight for age. Distance 1 mile.

Mr. E. Karam’s cb.a.b. Florist, 9.11. Hassan Soliman. 1 Ibrahim Bey Cherif's b.a.h. Chendi, 10.7. Capt Leigh 2 Mr. A. J. 8ursock’s ch.a.b. Damon (late Ko¬rosko 11), 10.7. Challoner. 3 Hassan Bey Kheir el Din’s b.a.h. Abou Gebel, 10.7 Koukidis. 4 Ibrahim Bey Cherif's b.a.h. Merawi, 10.7. Burnham 0 Mr. B. A. P. Schreiber’s b.a.h. Flying Fish, 10.7. 0

Chendi jumped off followed by Abou Gebal and soon got a long lead, which be maintained until reaching the 5 furlong post. Here Florist, who had been lying last, was sent to the front and came out of the cutting some lengths ahead of Chendi, who could never make up lost ground and came in second to Florist by a length. Damon (late Korosko II.) was one length behind, third. Time : 1.53.
Totalisator paid P.T. 34 on winner and P.T. 19, 25, and 39 for places.

GALLOWAY PLATE of P.T. 2,500, viz: P.T. 2.000 to winner and P.T. 500 to 2nd horse. For Arab Galloways that have never won a race of the net value of P.T. 2,000 or more. Weight for age and inches. Distance 1 mile.

Ishak Bey Hussein's g.a.p. Fadghan, 9.1. Thompson. 1 Saleh Bey Yaghen’s g.a.p. India, 9.1. Abdallah.2 Mr. A. J. Sursock's br.a.h. Nigri, 10.3. Challoner. 3 Baron J. E de Menasce’s b.a.p. Viking, 9.9. Matthews. 0 Ibrahim Bey Cherif's g.a.b. Kordofan, 9.7. Burnham. 0 Ibrahim Bey Cherif's g.a.b. Korti, 10.7. Capt. Leigh. 0 Mr. E. Karam's ch a.b. Ladase, 10.3. Hassan Soliman. 0 Hassan Bey Kheir el Din's g.a.h. Koraishen (late Mastour). 10.1. Koukidis.

Nigri and Viking were the first off to a good start, but as neither of them seemed to wish to make the pace it was taken up by Fadghan, who was closely followed by Kordofan. Fadghan, on entering the straight, had a lead of three lengths, and never once being challenged won comfortably by a couple of lengths from India, Nigri just losing second place by half a length. Time : 1.52.
Totalisator paid P.T. 37 on winner and P.T. 22, 29, and 41 for places,

SELLING RACE of P.T. 2,000. For Arabs that have not won a selling race since 1st January 1903 Winner to be sold for P.T.5,000. 7 lbs allowed for every P.T. 1,000 less than that price. Top weight 11.0. Distance 5 furlongs. Hussein Pasha 8ioufi and Kamel Effendi Maher’s b.a.p. Sweeti, 11.0. Kamel Effendi. 1 Mr. E. Karam’s g.a.h Voltigeur 10.7. Hassan Soliman. 2 Mr. A. J. 8ursock’s ch.a.p. Hotspur, 9.7. Chal- loner. 3 Mr. A. J. Michaelides’ br.a.p. El Mass 10 0. Batty. 4 Mr. B.A.P. Schreiber’s g.ah. Flying Fish, 11.0. 0 Ishak Bey Hussein's b.a.p. Kamboula, 9 7. Thompson. 0,

Sweetie made all the running and coming out of the cutting had a clear lead of five lengths, which he maintained all the way home, winning as he liked by three lengths, acou le of lengths seperating second and third. Time : 1.9.
Totalisator paid P.T. 28 on winner, and P.T. 21, 26, and 41 for places.

BULKELEY PLATE of P.T. 1,250. viz : P.T. 1,000 to the winner and P.T. 250 to 2nd horse. For Arab ponies that have not won a race since 1st April 1906 Weight for age and inches with penalties Distance round the course. Ishak Bey Hussein’s g.a.p. Fadghan, 9.2. Fenwick. 1 Ibrahim Bey Cherif's g a.p. Kara Aslan, 9 3. Burnham. 2 8aleh Bey Yaghen’s gap. India, 9.2. Abdallah. 3 Mr. A. J. Sursock’s b.a.p. Sans Pareil, 9.7. Batty. 4 Saleh Bey Yaghen’s b.a.p. Bulkeley. 9.3. Cla¬ridge. 0 Khalil Pasha Khayat’s g.a.p. Sadik, 10.7. Thompson. 0

Kara Aslan jumped off and made the run¬ning at a great pace until the mile post, fol¬lowed by Bulkeley. On entering the cutting Kara Aslan gave place to Fadghan, but soon regained the lead, showing the way out to Fadghan and India. In the straight the race lay between Fadghan and Kara Aslan, but the latter could not maintain the pace and lost first place by a head. Three lengths divided second and third. Time : 2.30.
Totalisator paid P.T. 37 on winner and P.T. 23, and 30 for places.

SIDI GABER PLATE of P.T. 1,250, viz: P.E 1,000 to the winner and P.T. 250 to 2nd horse. For Arabs that have not won a race since the 1st April 1906. Weight for age with penalties. Distance round the course. Messrs. A. J. Sursock's and A. J. Michaelides' g.a.h. Jupiter. 9 7. Challoner. 1 8aleh Bey Yaghen’s ga.b.g. Mizzaud, 9.4. Koukidis. 2 Ishak Bey Hussein’s b.a.h. Moofid, 9.7. Fen¬wick 3 Khalil Pasha Khayat's g.a h. Sinounou, 10.0. Thompson. 0 Mr. E. Karam's ch.a.h. Florist, 8 11. Hassan Soliman. 0 Ibrahim Bey Cherif’s b.a h. Valentino, 10.3. Clements. 0 Ibrahim Bey Cherif's b.a.h. Chendi, 9.7. Burnham. 0

Sinounou was the first away from a bad start, but Chendi made the running from the mile post to the 5 furlongs, when Sinounou took it up and led into the cutting with Florist. Coming out, Moofid was seen to be leading, with Mizzaud and Jupiter at his heels. Jupiter came with a clatter in the straight and won by two lengths from Mizzaud, Moofid being placed third, one length behind. Time: 2.34 Totalisator paid P.T. 332 on winner, and P.T. 37,47, and 38 for places.

div.head: HOME CRICKET
div.p: Cricket.—Kent beat Somerset by 354 runs. Yorkshire beat Warwickshire by an innings and 90 runs. West Indians beat Northamptonshire by 155 runs. Hampshire beat Worcestershire by 131 runs. Notts beat Middlesex by wickets. Lancashire beat Surrey by 6 wickets. (R.)

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: H.H. Prince Aziz Hassan arrived at Venice on Saturday week on his steam yacht Cuhona, with a party on board.
The Earl and Countess of Cromer have left London for Cromer.
H E. Hussein Pasha Fakhry, Minister of Public Works, returns here from France on September 4
Sir Mclcolm Mcllwraith, the Judicial Ad-viser, leaves England for Cairo at the end of September.
Mr. J. M. Farness, M.A., headmaster of Richmond 8chool, Yorkshire, late scholar of King's College Cambridge, has been appointed to the headmastership of Khedivieh School, Cairo.
A Reuter's telegram from London states that the writer, Miss Elizabeth Missing Sewell, is dead.
Mme Luigi Steinschoeider, who is at present at Lucerne, intends to return to Egypt this winter.
M. Aranias, professor of the Israelite Insti¬tute, at Cairo, has been arrested by the Stamboul authorities on the pretext that his passport was not in order.

div.head: EDEN PALACE HOTEL,
div.p: CAIRO. NOTED FOR ITS EXCELLENT CUISINE, ELECTRIC LIGHT. LIFT. Special terms for officers of the Army of Occupation and Government Officials.

div.head: Geneva, Switzerland. (Magnificent Spring Resort.)
div.p: GRAND HOTEL NATIONAL THE LEADING FIRST CLASS HOTEL Large Park, Tennis, Sport Ground. Situated on the lake, opposite Mont Blane,

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: ( Aujourd’ hui a midi et demie.) On a pea travaille de toute la matinee. Les affaires se sont limitess aux memes valeurs que les jours precedents.
Quant aux fluctuations, elles indiquent en general une nouvelle baisse.
L’Agricole recule a 9 23/32, la National Bank a 26, l’Obligation Credit Foncier Egyptien a 334.
La Cassa di Sconto s’inscrit a 219 1/2 ex coupon l’ancienne. La nouvelle perd 1 franc a 213 3/4.
De 3 17/32 les Delta Land flechissent a 3 7/16.
Le Comptoir Financier reactionne de 1/32 tant aur l’ancienne a 6 1/2 que sur la nouvelle a 6 3/8. La part de fondateur perd 1 livre a 43
L’Union Fonciere est ferme a 6 1/4 et les Nungovich Hotels s’avancent meme a 17 1/8

II y a eu ce matin un certain mouvement sur les Port Said Salt et lea Heliopolis. Ces derniers, apres avoir debute a 340 scheteurs, ont flechi a 315 vendeurs, pour finir en c’oture a 330. Le comptant vaut 10 francs de plus que les trois mois, en raison du decouvert qui existe sur ce titre.

div.head: SHIPPING MOVEMENTS
div.p: ALEXANDRIA HARBOUR.

August 19. Singapore, Ital. s. capt. Raggio, Genoa and Messina, Florio Rubattino. Bear, Brit. s. capt Wright, Cyprus and Port Said, Moss amd Co.

August 20. Semiramis, Aust. s. capt Martinolich, Trieste and Brindisi, Austrian Loyd. Britannia, Brit. s. capt. Rawlings, Fernosand and Hull. Borjom, RUS. s. capt Sallus, Batoum and Cavak, Mantachoff. Irini, Greek s. capt Mastrogiorgiu, Canea and Cassos, Ismiridi. Midlothian, Brit. s. capt. Shearer, Leith and Malta, Grace and Co.

DEPARTURES August 18. Habsburg, Aust s. capt. Klausberger, Brindisi and Trieste. Magda, Greek s. capt. Papalas, Constantinople. Kosseir, Brit s. capt. Winter, Syria. Athenes, Greek s. capt. Catramatos, Piraeus and Crete. Korniloft, Rus. s. capt. Copaicich, Constantinople and Odessa. Ariadne, Brit s. capt. Webb, Kertch, in ballast. Cowrie, Brit. s. capt Donnel, Port 8aid, in ballast. Bussard, Germ. s. capt. Brummer, Stax, in ballast. Enosis, Greek s. capt. Ambatiollos, Taganrog, in ballast Elswick Tower, Brit. s. capt. Berlin, Constan-tinople, in ballast. Alba M., Ital. s. capt. Cacace, Naples, in ballast. Britannia, Ital. tug capt. Biagini, Genoa.

August 19. Persian Prince, Brit. s. capt. Bell, Beyrouth, with part of previous cargo. Gemelli, Ital. s. cap. Jacons, Naples, in ballast. Derwin, Brit. s. cap. Jenkens, 0 lessa, in ballast. Alep, Ott. s. cap. Demetrio, Syria, in ballast.

div.head: EXPORT MANIFESTS.
div.p: For 8YRIA, by the S.S. Portugal, sailed on the 9th August : Various, 103 packages sundries

For SYRIA, by the S.S. Minieb, sailed on the 11th August : Various, 604 bags rice, 410 bags coffee, 30 bags drugs, 25 bags Sudan beans, 54 bags potatoes, 60 bags flour, 300 bags sugar, 90 cases sugar,ll cases glass works, 18 cases soap, 4 cases oil, 13 cases furniture, 12 cases iron¬mongery,623 packages ironmongery, 19 bales empty bags, 6 packages henna, 737 packa¬ges sundriee

For CRETE, by the S.S. Byzantion, sailed on the 11th August : Various, 51 bales skins. 40 bales cotton thread, 19 bales manufacture, 872 bags rice, 11 empty demi johns, 348 empty casks, 13 packages sundries

For PIRAEUS and ODESSA, by the S.S. Tchihatchoff, sailed on the 14th August : Various, 30 bags cotton, 35 packages palms, 28 packages sundries Mohr and Fenderl, 25 bales cotton Choremi, Benachi and Co., 50 „ „ 75 bales cotton
For BRINDISI and VENICE, by the S.S. Nilo, sailed on the 15th August :
FOR VARIOUS FORTS Various, 184 empty casks, 12 packages sundries
FOR VENICE Fenderl, 17 bales cot on Various, 24 packages sundries
